neighborhoods.name: Vieux Lyon
neighborhoods.character: A UNESCO World Heritage site and one of Europe's largest Renaissance districts with narrow cobblestone streets, hidden traboules (passageways), and a vibrant atmosphere that captures the essence of historic Lyon.

location.description: Situated on the west bank of the Saône River at the foot of Fourvière Hill, Vieux Lyon spans three parishes: Saint-Jean (central), Saint-Paul (north), and Saint-Georges (south).

history.overview: Developed primarily in the 15th and 16th centuries when Lyon was a major European banking center and silk trading hub, Vieux Lyon features remarkable preservation of Renaissance architecture and urban planning.
history.significance: Represents Lyon's golden age of commerce and cultural exchange with Italy, evident in the Italian architectural influences throughout the quarter.
notable_events: Served as commercial and financial center in the Renaissance
Narrowly escaped demolition in the 1960s thanks to preservation efforts

practical_info.safety: Generally very safe, though pickpocketing can occur in crowded tourist areas. Exercise normal precautions.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Early morning or evening to avoid crowds; particularly magical at dusk when buildings are illuminated.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable but entirely pedestrianized with cobblestone streets that may challenge those with mobility issues.

attractions.name: Cathédrale Saint-Jean-Baptiste
attractions.description: 12th-15th century cathedral featuring an astronomical clock and remarkable stained glass windows.
attractions.appeal: Impressive medieval architecture and religious significance.

attractions.name: Traboules
attractions.description: Hidden corridors running between buildings and courtyards, originally used by silk workers.
attractions.appeal: Unique architectural feature offering a glimpse into Lyon's secretive past.

attractions.name: Musée Gadagne
attractions.description: Housed in a Renaissance mansion, featuring the Lyon History Museum and International Puppet Museum.
attractions.appeal: Comprehensive insight into Lyon's history with beautiful period rooms.

dining.name: Daniel et Denise
dining.known_for: Authentic bouchon cuisine by Meilleur Ouvrier de France chef Joseph Viola
dining.atmosphere: Classic bouchon with red-and-white checkered tablecloths

dining.name: Le Café du Soleil
dining.known_for: Hearty local specialties served in a historic setting

activities.name: Traboules Tour
activities.description: Explore the hidden passageways connecting buildings and courtyards throughout Vieux Lyon.

activities.name: Puppet Show at Théâtre Le Guignol
activities.description: Watch a traditional performance featuring Guignol, the famous puppet character created in Lyon.

stay_here_if: You want to immerse yourself in Lyon's Renaissance history
You enjoy atmospheric dining and active nightlife
You prefer historic surroundings with easy access to main attractions
avoid_if: You have mobility issues (cobblestones and stairs)
You're sensitive to noise (can be lively at night)
You prefer modern amenities and spacious accommodations
insider_tips: Many traboules are public but unmarked - look for small plaques or push door handles to check if they're open.
Visit on weekday mornings to have the most peaceful experience exploring the quarter.
The courtyard at 27 rue Saint-Jean has some of the most impressive Renaissance architecture but is often overlooked by tourists.

neighborhoods.name: La Croix-Rousse
neighborhoods.character: A bohemian, village-like district with a strong identity rooted in its silk-weaving history, now known for its artistic community, markets, and panoramic views of Lyon.

location.description: Located on a hill north of central Lyon, La Croix-Rousse is divided into the slopes (les pentes) and the plateau, rising above the Saône and Rhône rivers with sweeping city views.

history.overview: Formerly a working-class district dominated by silk workers (canuts) in the 19th century, whose workshops with high ceilings accommodated the Jacquard looms used in silk production.
history.significance: The heart of Lyon's silk industry and site of the canuts' revolts of the 1830s, important events in French labor history.
notable_events: Development of the Jacquard loom revolutionizing silk production
Resistance activity during World War II

transit: Metro C to Croix-Rousse or Hénon (plateau)
practical_info.safety: Very safe neighborhood popular with families and young professionals.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Tuesday-Sunday mornings for the market, afternoons for exploring the slopes.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable but prepare for substantial inclines on the slopes.

attractions.name: Marché de la Croix-Rousse
attractions.description: One of Lyon's best markets, stretching along Boulevard de la Croix-Rousse with over 100 vendors.
attractions.appeal: Exceptional local produce, regional specialties, and vibrant atmosphere.

attractions.name: Maison des Canuts
attractions.description: Museum dedicated to Lyon's silk-working tradition with demonstrations of Jacquard looms.
attractions.appeal: Insight into the technical innovation and social history of Lyon's silk industry.

attractions.name: Mur des Canuts
attractions.description: France's largest trompe l'oeil mural depicting life in La Croix-Rousse, updated periodically.
attractions.appeal: Remarkable artistic achievement and cultural landmark showing neighborhood evolution.

activities.name: Slopes Exploration
activities.description: Wander the steep streets, staircases, and traboules connecting Presqu'île to the plateau.

activities.name: Artisan Workshops
activities.description: Visit independent artisans continuing the creative tradition of the neighborhood.

stay_here_if: You want an authentic, non-touristy Lyon experience
You enjoy village atmosphere with city conveniences
You appreciate creative scenes and markets
avoid_if: You have mobility issues (many steep streets and stairs)
You want immediate access to major tourist attractions
insider_tips: The best views of Lyon are from the Gros Caillou landmark at the north end of the plateau.
Explore the 'pentes' (slopes) section for the most interesting independent shops and restaurants.
Visit the traboule at 9 place Colbert to see a six-story straight staircase, an architectural marvel.

neighborhoods.name: Presqu'île
neighborhoods.character: The elegant central district between Lyon's two rivers, featuring grand squares, 19th-century architecture, luxury shopping, and a sophisticated urban atmosphere.

location.description: A narrow peninsula between the Rhône and Saône rivers, forming Lyon's city center and main commercial district, stretching from Perrache in the south to the Croix-Rousse hill in the north.

history.overview: Transformed in the 19th century under Prefect Vaïsse (Lyon's Haussmann), who created wide boulevards and grand buildings, replacing medieval streets with the elegant district seen today.
history.significance: Represents Lyon's prosperity and importance as a major European city during the Industrial Revolution and Belle Époque periods.
notable_events: Construction of grand boulevards and squares
Development as Lyon's commercial and cultural center

transit: Metro lines A and D cross the peninsula
Tram T1 and T2 along the Rhône side
practical_info.safety: Very safe area with police presence, though standard city precautions apply, especially at night.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Weekdays for shopping, weekends for atmosphere, evenings for dining.
practical_info.walkability: Extremely walkable with wide sidewalks and pedestrianized areas.

attractions.name: Place Bellecour
attractions.description: One of Europe's largest open squares featuring a statue of Louis XIV and unobstructed views of Fourvière Hill.
attractions.appeal: The central point of Lyon and a major gathering place for events and celebrations.

attractions.name: Musée des Beaux-Arts
attractions.description: Housed in a former 17th-century abbey, one of France's largest and finest art collections outside Paris.
attractions.appeal: World-class collection spanning antiquity to modern art in a magnificent setting.

attractions.name: Place des Terreaux
attractions.description: Elegant square featuring Bartholdi's fountain, the Hôtel de Ville (City Hall), and the Fine Arts Museum.
attractions.appeal: Cultural heart of Lyon with beautiful architecture and vibrant cafe scene.

dining.name: Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse
Brasserie Georges
dining.known_for: Classic French dishes in historic setting (est. 1836)

activities.name: Luxury Shopping
activities.description: Explore the boutiques along rue de la République and rue Édouard Herriot.

activities.name: Opera Performance
activities.description: Attend a performance at the striking contemporary Opéra National de Lyon in a renovated historic building.

stay_here_if: You want to be at the heart of Lyon's shopping and dining scene
You prefer central location with easy access to major attractions
You enjoy elegant surroundings and urban energy
avoid_if: You prefer to avoid tourist centers and higher prices
You want extensive green spaces nearby
insider_tips: The passages of the Cour des Loges between rue Saint-Jean and rue du Boeuf contain some of Lyon's best-preserved Renaissance architecture.
For the best view of Place Bellecour, visit the rooftop terrace of Galeries Lafayette department store.
Many restaurants close on Sundays and Mondays; plan accordingly or head to Rue Mercière, which has options open daily.

neighborhoods.name: Confluence
neighborhoods.character: Lyon's newest district showcasing bold contemporary architecture, sustainable urban planning, and cultural innovation at the meeting point of the Rhône and Saône rivers.

location.description: Located at the southernmost tip of the Presqu'île where the Rhône and Saône rivers meet, formerly an industrial area now transformed into a modern urban development.

history.overview: Historically an industrial and port area that fell into decline, Confluence has been the site of one of Europe's largest urban renewal projects since the early 2000s.
history.significance: Represents Lyon's commitment to sustainable development and architectural innovation for the 21st century.
notable_events: Opening of the Confluence Shopping Center in 2012
Inauguration of the Musée des Confluences in 2014

transit: Tram T1 runs through the district
Perrache train and metro station nearby
practical_info.safety: Very safe, modern area with good lighting and security features.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Daytime for architecture viewing, sunset for riverfront atmosphere.
practical_info.walkability: Extremely walkable with wide promenades and pedestrian-friendly design.

attractions.name: Musée des Confluences
attractions.description: A striking deconstructivist building housing natural history, anthropology, and society exhibitions.
attractions.appeal: Both architectural marvel and fascinating museum concept exploring human knowledge.

attractions.name: Place Nautique
attractions.description: Central water feature with pleasure boats and surrounded by restaurants and terraces.
attractions.appeal: Vibrant gathering place showcasing the district's connection to its rivers.

attractions.name: Architectural Walking Tour
attractions.description: Route passing distinctive buildings like the Orange Cube, Euronews headquarters, and sustainable housing projects.
attractions.appeal: Showcase of contemporary architectural innovation from renowned international architects.

dining.name: The Cousu
dining.known_for: Creative menu in Musée des Confluences

activities.name: Riverside Promenade
activities.description: Follow the landscaped pathways along both rivers to the actual confluence point.

activities.name: Confluence Shopping Center
activities.description: Eco-designed mall featuring retail, dining, and entertainment options.

stay_here_if: You appreciate contemporary architecture and design
You enjoy waterfront settings and don't mind being slightly removed from historic areas
avoid_if: You're primarily interested in historic architecture
You want to be in the heart of traditional Lyon
insider_tips: Visit La Sucrière, a former sugar warehouse converted to exhibition space that hosts many contemporary art events.
The best photography spot is from the tip of the peninsula where both rivers visibly meet.
Take the river shuttle (Vaporetto) from Vieux Lyon for a scenic approach to the district.

neighborhoods.name: Fourvière
neighborhoods.character: A sacred hill overlooking Lyon with Roman ruins, the iconic basilica, and breathtaking panoramic views, representing the spiritual heritage of the city.

location.description: Situated on the west bank of the Saône River, this steep hill rises dramatically above Vieux Lyon and offers commanding views of the entire city.

history.overview: Site of the original Roman settlement of Lugdunum founded in 43 BCE, later becoming a religious center with the construction of the Fourvière Basilica in the 19th century.
history.significance: Represents both the Roman origins of Lyon and its strong Catholic tradition, contrasting with Croix-Rousse ('the hill that works').
notable_events: Roman foundation of Lugdunum in 43 BCE
Construction of the Basilica (1872-1884) fulfilling a vow during the Franco-Prussian War
Annual Festival of Lights (December 8) centered around the illuminated Basilica

transit: Funicular from Vieux Lyon (quick and scenic)
practical_info.safety: Very safe area popular with tourists and pilgrims.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Morning for clearer views; avoid midday heat in summer; magical during Festival of Lights in December.
practical_info.walkability: The hilltop area is walkable but steep; the funicular is recommended for access.

attractions.name: Basilique Notre-Dame de Fourvière
attractions.description: 19th-century basilica with stunning mosaics, ornate interiors, and a distinctive silhouette visible throughout Lyon.
attractions.appeal: Religious significance, architectural splendor, and incredible city views from its esplanade.

attractions.name: Théâtres Romains de Fourvière
attractions.description: Well-preserved ancient Roman theater and odeon dating from 15 BCE, still used for summer performances.
attractions.appeal: Remarkable Roman ruins with excellent educational displays in an atmospheric setting.

attractions.name: Musée Gallo-Romain
attractions.description: Modern museum built into the hillside adjacent to the Roman theaters, housing exceptional Roman artifacts.
attractions.appeal: Comprehensive collection including mosaics, sculptures, and everyday items from Lugdunum.

dining.name: Les Terrasses de Fourvière
dining.known_for: Panoramic dining with views of Lyon

dining.name: L'Antiquaille
dining.known_for: Located in a historic hospital complex

activities.name: Nuits de Fourvière Festival
activities.description: Summer performance festival held in the Roman theaters featuring music, dance, theater, and circus arts.

activities.name: Fourvière Hill Gardens
activities.description: Peaceful gardens surrounding the basilica with walking paths and viewpoints.

stay_here_if: You value spectacular views and don't mind the climb
You're interested in Roman history and religious heritage
You prefer quiet surroundings away from urban bustle
avoid_if: You have mobility issues (steep terrain throughout)
You want convenient access to restaurants and nightlife
You prefer centrally located accommodation near shopping
insider_tips: Visit the rooftop terraces of the basilica (separate ticket required) for the absolute best views of Lyon.
Time your visit to the Roman theaters in the early morning or late afternoon for the best photography light.
Take the path behind the basilica for less-known viewpoints and a peaceful walk through gardens.
